items.title: zipp package in dependency requires Python 3.6+
items.body:
Hello,

I'm facing an issue with the project [django-macaddress](http://github.com/tubaman/django-macaddress) especially with this PR : 

https://github.com/django-macaddress/django-macaddress/pull/39

I'm pushing to use tox-travis.
The configuration is pretty straight forward but the travis fails with Python 3.5 with this message :

https://travis-ci.org/github/django-macaddress/django-macaddress/builds/715081813

```zipp requires Python '>=3.6' but the running Python is 3.5.6
306The command "pip install tox-travis" failed and exited with 1 during .```

Any idea ?

Thanks

items.title: build failing  -> restart build
items.body:
Hi,

currently there is a ugly red broken build badge on this repos start page - just because a couple of months ago there was a hiccup when downloading a specific python version.

https://travis-ci.org/github/tox-dev/tox-travis/jobs/647235234

Could any maintainer trigger a new build? Or even better, activate weekly builds? So we get to know early when something breaks.

Thanks!

P.S.: Also thanks for this great piece of software!

items.title: make tox version configurable
items.body: Is there a way to configure the tox version being used?

items.title: Update link in description
items.body:
The link in the description for this GitHub repository points to https://tox-travis.readthedocs.io which then gets redirected to https://tox-travis.readthedocs.io/en/stable/

This documentation is pretty old, and still contains references to Python 2.6, e.g at the bottom of https://tox-travis.readthedocs.io/en/stable/contributing.html 

While this might be ok for a link at PyPi (as there it is bound to the release), I'd like the link here at the GitHub repository to link to the latest version of the documentation, e.g.
https://tox-travis.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ (which is more up to date).

items.title: Tox 3.4.0 broke tox-travis
items.body:
Not sure if this is a regression in tox or if tox-travis needs to be updated.

```
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6.3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tox_travis/hooks.py", line 46, in tox_configure
    autogen_envconfigs(config, undeclared)
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6.3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tox_travis/envlist.py", line 48, in autogen_envconfigs
    make_envconfig = tox.config.parseini.make_envconfig
AttributeError: module 'tox.config' has no attribute 'parseini'
```

See 
https://travis-ci.org/devpi/devpi/builds/431142175

and https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/1011

items.title: Use basepython env param by default
items.body:
We have config:
```ini
[tox]
envlist = py35, py36, docs
skipsdist = true

[testenv]
skip_install = true
commands = python --version

[testenv:docs]
basepython = python3.5
```
When we run `tox` locally we get 3 tests. And `docs` will run with `basepython` python.
When we run `tox` on travis we don't run 'docs' test on Python 3.5.
I know that i can do `[travis] python = 3.5: py35, docs`,
but maybe it will useful have this behavior by default?

items.title: Why are CODECOV_* environment variables are not being passed through?
items.body:
Hi,

I have a question regarding environment variables used in `[commands]`

I am using travis, I have created a custom tox.ini file and the idea is to upload the coverage with codecov

This is my `.travis.yml`:
```
language: python

python:
  - "2.7"
  - "3.5"

# command to install dependencies, e.g. pip install -r requirements.txt --use-mirrors
install: pip install tox-travis

script: tox
```
and this is my `.tox.ini`:

```
[tox]
envlist = py27,py36

[travis]
python =
  2.7: py27
  3.6: py36

[testenv]
passenv = CI TRAVIS
deps =
  coverage
  codecov

commands =
  echo CODECOV_TOKEN
  coverage run --source=sound_downloader -m unittest discover
  coverage report -m
  codecov --token CODECOV_TOKEN
```
For some reason seems that `CODECOV_TOKEN` is empty. I have set the option "display value in build log" in travis and the variable is correct:

```
Setting environment variables from repository settings
$ export CODECOV_TOKEN=xxxxxxxxxxxxx
```
Any ideas?


Best regards,

Marcos.

items.title: Improve docs about tox virtualenv test environment configuration
items.body:
How need [`tox` virtualenv test environments [testenv:NAME]](http://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html?highlight=envlist#virtualenv-test-environment-settings) to be configured that they are executed as Travis jobs? Right now I use the default `tox-travis` configuration in my [.travis.yml](https://github.com/fkromer/rospbt/blob/master/.travis.yml) and a [tox.ini](https://github.com/fkromer/rospbt/blob/master/tox.ini) with `envlist` for the Python interpreters and `testenv:...`s for tox jobs.

1. How could I run one tox testenv (e.g. `[testenv:tests]`) with one (`envlist=pypy`) Python interpreter?
2. How could I run one tox testenv (e.g. `[testenv:tests]`) with all Python interpreters (`envlist = py27, py34, py35, pypy`)?
3. How could I run several tox testenvs (e.g. `[testenv:tests]`, `[testenv:lint]`) with one (`envlist=pypy`) Python interpreter?
4. How could I run several tox testenvs (e.g. `[testenv:tests]`, `[testenv:lint]`) with all Python interpreters (`envlist = py27, py34, py35, pypy`)?  ("Merge" of 2. and 3. config?)

items.title: Hide main functionality behind a flag
items.body:
I'm debating whether it would be wise to require the detection to be behind a flag, the same way that after all is behind a flag, and that any other feature would also be behind a flag. Magic is best used sparingly and judiciously.

There are some places that I think magic is the only thing that makes sense. In particular, our hacks, of which there is currently only one, that allows the pypy3 pre-releases to work on Travis. There's no sense in doing that less magically.

The argument for the general detection behavior being behind a flag, however, is that it allows tox to run the same on Travis as it does locally. It's easy enough to add a flag in `tox_addoption`. Explicit opt-in allows users to decide exactly what they do (and don't) want overridden.

A future case where this might play out is if someone wishes to Tox-Travis for its ability to report back to GitHub (#73), but want to do all of that in a single job. It really shouldn't require a bunch of extra configuration work to do what Tox does by default.

An alternative would be a flag to _disable_ detection. That would be a backward compatible change, and would give the needed functionality, but it would have the flag being backward from rest of the features, which are (and are going to be) opt-in.

items.title: Rename toxenv
items.body:
We use the name `toxenv` in several places, because the `TOXENV` environment variable is the mechanism I used to implement the primary feature of Env Detection. When #78 is merged, it will no longer be used, except to make sure we don't do anything if it's already been given. So let's not use it as a name.

Some places that I know it's used:

* [ ] The name of the module that implements env detection. (Rename to `detect` or `envlist`)
* [ ] The name of the function that implements env detection. (Name the same as the module above)
* [ ] The name of the file with the documentation for env detection. (Name the same as those above)
* [ ] The name of the setting for the `[travis:after]` section that says which envs to look for. (Either the same as the above, or perhaps just `env`. Keep the current name for backward compatibility.)

items.title: What is simplest Travis config for full Django matrix?
items.body:
I'm maintaining a few Django packages, and running a matrix build against all supported Python/Django combinations is what we typically do.

Now I'm wondering, what the simplest Travis setup is for a full build matrix for Django (say, all Django versions >= 1.7 by their supported Python versions). I really want to avoid doing things twice, or things that overlap, in two different configuration files, `tox.ini` and `.travis.yml`.

Example `tox.ini` and `.travis.yml`
=============
Let's omit Python 3.2 for heaven's sake (all the packages seem to drop support anyway) and let's add `flake8`. Here's what I have come up with:

```ini
# -- FILE: tox.ini
[tox]
envlist =
    py{27,33,34}-django17
    py{27,33,34,35}-django18
    py{27,34,35}-django19
    py{27,34,35}-django110
    py{27,34,35,36}-django111
    flake8

[testenv]
commands =
    coverage run setup.py test
deps =
    coverage
    django17: Django>=1.7,<1.8
    django18: Django>=1.8,<1.9
    django19: Django>=1.9,<1.10
    django110: Django>=1.10,<1.11
    django111: Django>=1.11,<2.0

[testenv:flake8]
basepython = python2.7
deps = flake8
commands = flake8

[travis:env]
DJANGO =
    1.7: django17
    1.8: django18
    1.9: django19
    1.10: django110
    1.11: django111
```

This is already longer than I want, but probably as short as it gets. Now for the worse:

```yaml
# -- FILE: .travis.yml
language: python
python:
  - 2.7
  - 3.3
  - 3.4
  - 3.5
  - 3.6
env:
  - DJANGO=1.7
  - DJANGO=1.8
  - DJANGO=1.9
  - DJANGO=1.10
  - DJANGO=1.11
matrix:
  exclude:
    - python: 3.5
      env: DJANGO=1.7
    - python: 3.6
      env: DJANGO=1.7
    - python: 3.6
      env: DJANGO=1.8
    - python: 3.3
      env: DJANGO=1.9
    - python: 3.6
      env: DJANGO=1.9
    - python: 3.3
      env: DJANGO=1.10
    - python: 3.6
      env: DJANGO=1.10
    - python: 3.3
      env: DJANGO=1.11
  include:
    - python: 2.7
      env: TOXENV=flake8

install:
  - pip install tox-travis
script:
  - tox
```

This is terribly long, and the `exclude:` section in the Travis configuration duplicates what is already specified in the Tox config, in a negative form, to make it all more complicated.  -- Is that really as simple as it gets, for a full build matrix?

The result we get looks somewhat like [Travis build #288326510](https://travis-ci.org/jcassee/django-analytical/builds/288326510), which is fine.

Can We Derive Environments Automatically?
==========================
I prefer to specify my "build matrix" in Tox, because that ensures that I can run the same set of checks and tests locally _and_ on a CI infrastructure. I only need to change a single file, that's how I want it.

Can I configure a much simpler `.travis.yml` that lets me avoid doing the same work twice?  Maybe have both the `env:` section and the `matrix: exclude: ` section be built automagically? With the same result as above, each combination listed as a separate job in the Travis build.

```yaml
# -- FILE: .travis.yml
language: python
python:
  - 2.7
  - 3.3
  - 3.4
  - 3.5
  - 3.6
matrix:
  include:
    - python: 2.7
      env: TOXENV=flake8

install:
  - pip install tox-travis
script:
  - tox
```
(That file doesn't do it, which is part of the question.)

Is something like that feasible at all? Is that already possible? If yes, what is missing for a concise solution?

What I Have Stopped Doing
===================
Let me mention what I have stopped doing, mainly due to the [limitations the Travis build images have](https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/4990) for Python since well over a year.

```yaml
#-- FILE: .travis.yml
language: python
python: "3.5"
install:
  - pip install tox
script:
  - tox
env:
  # NOTE: To generate (update) the env list run
  # $ tox -l | sort | xargs -I ITEM echo "  - TOXENV="ITEM
  - TOXENV=py27-django17
  - TOXENV=py27-django18
  - TOXENV=py27-django19
  - TOXENV=py27-django110
  - TOXENV=py27-django111
  - TOXENV=py33-django17
  - TOXENV=py33-django18
  - TOXENV=py34-django17
  - TOXENV=py34-django18
  - TOXENV=py34-django19
  - TOXENV=py34-django110
  - TOXENV=py34-django111
  - TOXENV=py35-django18
  - TOXENV=py35-django19
  - TOXENV=py35-django110
  - TOXENV=py35-django111
  - TOXENV=py36-django111
```

This is less stable than builds with dedicated Python versions and requires some manual maintenance (demonstrated by the NOTE comment in the code). It is technically though the result we need:

- The `env:` section lists the jobs we would want to otherwise generate with a `tox-travis` solution,
- or by simply a  `matrix: include: ` section with a full list of Python/Django combinations (which would be double the lines of code of the `env:` section, though).

Please let me know your thoughts!

items.title: Counterintuitive passthru behavior
items.body:
When nothing matched tox-travis for whatever reason runs all tox envs. Here is [an example](https://travis-ci.org/Suor/django-cacheops/builds/275975110) - there is no `pypy-djmaster` env in envlist.

One would expect either `TOXENV=pypy-djmaster tox` be run anyway or empty run. Full run is quite surprising.

items.title: Please note the discussion in the tox project
items.body:
Hi, sorry for cluttering your issues, but I would like to note that we are discussing ways of better Travis integration for tox and we look at different options. This project has been mentioned there, so I would like to invite you to join the exchange.

Export support for travis: https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/562

items.title: Consider deprecating travis:after in favor of Build Stages
items.body:
https://blog.travis-ci.com/2017-05-11-introducing-build-stages

I don't have any plans to remove travis:after, but with the announcement of build stages for Travis, I'm watching it closely, and considering whether it will fully cover the use-cases that travis:after does. I suspect that it will end up as the better option, and that we will end up adding a note to the docs declaring that the better fix.

Right now it's still early days, and we need to watch and see. There are still bugs in this beta feature that need to be ironed out, but I'm very glad to see Travis supporting this feature natively.

thanks for this great plugin.

I just tried it and everything works fine, except the fact that the coverage is decreased, before it was 100% and now it's 98% because some code is executed only on specific django versions.

When I run tox ( `coverage run --append ...` ) the coverage is 100%.
It seems that the --append option doesn't work properly.

This is the involved repo: https://github.com/fabiocaccamo/django-maintenance-mode

items.title: Using with PyPy 3 5.5?
items.body:
[I'm stuck...](https://github.com/berkerpeksag/astor/pull/56)

Right now, I have:

## travis.yml

```yaml
sudo: false  # run travis jobs in containers
language: python
python:
  - "2.6"
  - "2.7"
  - "3.3"
  - "3.4"
  - "3.5"
  - "3.6"
  - pypy
  - "pypy3.3-5.5-alpha"
cache:
  directories:
    - $PWD/wheelhouse  # cache wheels so that we don't hit network everytime
env:
  global:
    - PIP_FIND_LINKS=$PWD/wheelhouse
install:
  - pip install tox-travis
script: tox
```

## tox.ini

```ini
[tox]
envlist = py26, py27, py33, py34, pypy, pypy3.3-5.5-alpha
skipsdist = True

[testenv]
usedevelop = True
commands = nosetests
deps =
 -rrequirements-tox.txt
 py26: unittest2
```

Travis reports that the PyPy3 version is 5.5, which is compatible with Python 3.3.5. BUT, when *pip* is run, it ends up (somehow?) using an old PyPy3 version and fails.

As a random guess, maybe [this line](https://github.com/ryanhiebert/tox-travis/blob/master/src/tox_travis/toxenv.py#L49) should also check for PyPy 5.5?

items.title: "Advanced configuration" not working as documented
items.body:
After reading [this](https://tox-travis.readthedocs.io/en/stable/toxenv.html#advanced-configuration), I created [this `.travis.yml`](https://github.com/posita/txrc/blob/802536857d8400db8cf4f340cf73797d39355544/.travis.yml) and [this `tox.ini`](https://github.com/posita/txrc/blob/802536857d8400db8cf4f340cf73797d39355544/tox.ini). However, my `lint`, and `check` targets are not being called as expected. I expected that (e.g):

- Python `"2.7"` and `TWISTED="17.1"` would call `py27-twisted_17_1` and `lint`, but [it only calls `py27-twisted_17_1`](https://travis-ci.org/posita/txrc/jobs/210718296#L238).
- Python `"3.5"` and `TWISTED="17.1"` would call `py35-twisted_17_1`, `lint`, and `check`, but [it only calls `py35-twisted_17_1`](https://travis-ci.org/posita/txrc/jobs/210718314#L226).

items.title: Env detection not working as expected
items.body:
I'm trying to a travis matrix to tox.
`.travis.yml`

```yaml
python:
  - '2.6'
  - '2.7'
  - '3.4'

env:
  matrix:
    include:
      - python: 3.4
        env: JYTHON="org.python;jython-installer;2.7.0"
```

`tox.ini`

```ini
[tox]
envlist = py{26,27,3}-driver-{hsqldb,mock,sqliteXerial},py27-driver-sqlitePy,jython-driver-{hsqldb,mock}

[travis]
python =
  2.6: py26-driver-{hsqldb,mock,sqliteXerial}
  2.7: py27-driver-{hsqldb,mock,sqliteXerial,sqlitePy}
  3.4: py34-driver-{hsqldb,mock,sqliteXerial}

[travis:env]
JYTHON =
  org.python;jython-installer;2.7.0: jython-driver-{hsqldb,mock}
```

(You can find the real code in [my feature branch](/baztian/jaydebeapi/tree/travis-tox))

[The build](https://travis-ci.org/baztian/jaydebeapi/builds/209340861) runs fine (the error is not related to tox mapping problems). But the Python 3.4 + Jython-Env entry doesn't get mapped as desired. It maps to all tox environments whereas I was expecting it to match to just the Jython environments (`jython-driver-{hsqldb,mock}`).

Am I doing something wrong or is this a bug?

items.title: Respect specified tox configuration file
items.body:
`tox -c CONFIGFILE` tells tox exactly where to find the Tox configuration file. This defaults to `tox.ini`. If this option is given, Tox-Travis should look for its configuration in that file as well.

References #56.

items.title: Incorrect/optimistic env matching?
items.body:
See https://github.com/tomchristie/django-rest-framework/pull/4842 for more info. In short, the `.travis.yml` file had a typo, including a build against django 1.18. However, it somehow matched against django 1.8.

Have we reached a point where interpreters account for typos?? Truly, this is a magical time. :smile:

items.title: Pass on allowed failures to Travis
items.body:
Currently I have a few environments that are allowed to fail. Without combining travis and tox these builds would show up as failed build jobs, but the overall build would succeed. 

However once combining tox and travis all the build jobs will show up as success; as `tox` will no longer report a failure to travis, in fact swallowing errors ([example][0]). So in order to report these failures to travis, I could remove `allowed_failures` from `tox.ini`. However when running tox locally, tox would also report those environments as failures.

Is there a way to achieve the following?

* When running with tox-travis, all failures from tox are reported to travis, effectively by-passing `allowed_failures`; (and it's up to the build matrix in `.travis.yml` to allow those failures).
* When running tox locally, take `allowed_failures` into account.

[0]: https://travis-ci.org/Bouke/django-user-sessions/jobs/189735034

items.title: Limit environments based on environment variable
items.body:
First off, great tool, scratches an itch I've been having. I have a question related to how to configure this to build the following. I want a different Travis job for each of the environments, to keep the history inside Travis easily browseable.

* [x] py{27,34,35}-{dj18,dj19,dj110} (see [here](https://travis-ci.org/Bouke/django-user-sessions/builds/189319558))
* [ ] flake8: this currently kicks off a build for all environments (see [here](https://travis-ci.org/Bouke/django-user-sessions/jobs/189319574)).

In my `tox.ini` I have the following; I would expect that setting `FLAKE8=YES` in the environment would restrict the envlist to only `flake8`;
```
[travis:env]
FLAKE8 =
    YES: flake8
```

Additionally I would like to enable code coverage for a selected few environments. So instead of `make test` it would need to be `make coverage`. This is probably a question for tox itself, but maybe there's a nice way to solve it integrally?

`travis.yml`
```
language: python
python:
 - 2.7
 - 3.4
 - 3.5
env:
 - DJANGO=1.8
 - DJANGO=1.9
 - DJANGO=1.10
matrix:
  include:
    - python: 3.5
      env: DJANGO=1.10 COVERAGE=YES
    - python: 3.5
      env: FLAKE8=YES
install: pip install tox-travis
script: tox
```

`tox.ini`
```[tox]
envlist =
    py{27,34,35}-{dj18,dj19,dj110},
    flake8

[travis]
python =
    2.7: py27
    3.4: py34
    3.5: py35

[travis:env]
DJANGO =
    1.8: dj18
    1.9: dj19
    1.10: dj110
FLAKE8 =
    YES: flake8

[testenv]
commands = make test
deps =
    dj18: Django>=1.8,<1.9
    dj19: Django>=1.9,<1.10
    dj110: Django>=1.10,<1.11
    flake8: flake8
whitelist_externals = make

[testenv:flake8]
commands = make flake8
```

items.title: Don't attempt after on pull requests
items.body:
Pull requests from another repository don't have the ability to read secure environment variables (rightly). There are two possible options:

1) Moving the secure environment variables to the web-based repository configuration may allow us to let the credentials go through to pull requests.
2) We could disable after for pull requests, or perhaps for pull requests _that aren't from this repository_.

Perhaps the right balance would be to check if it's a pull request, and if so, allow missing required environment variables for after waiting to just mean that after waiting is disabled.

Possibly related to #42. Problem showed up in #45.

items.title: Make toxenv match run environments
items.body:
Currently the `toxenv` after all option looks at the TOXENV environment variable. This is mostly useful, because it's quite common to set that environment variable to control tox, and tox-travis uses it under the hood.

However, it fails in a couple of cases:

1. No TOXENV is set. This is mostly a non-concern for us, because we always set it.
2. `-e env` is given to `tox`. This is the more annoying part, because it _might_ be used. It's a reasonable limitation for a first version, but there's probably going to be someone somewhere that is surprised by this, and I won't blame them.

What I'd like to do, if possible, is inspect Tox's run somehow, so that I know which envs were actually run, and match against those instead of relying on the environment variable.

items.title: Inspect deploy.on travis section for after:all
items.body:
For my own use-cases, I expect that the `travis:after` section will quite likely exactly match the `deploy.on` section of `.travis.yml` to whatever extent is possible. To that end, it may be a helpful shortcut to go ahead and have a configuration option that will allow it to inherit those settings automatically.

If it really works well for most people, we may choose even to have that be the default if no `travis:after` section is filled in. The after all feature is silently disabled if there is no `travis:after` section, so this would end up being a better default. Technically slightly backward incompatible, but I think reasonably so, if the most common use-case is indeed deployment.

Anyone who cares to comment, what do you think? Is deployment the most common use-case? Should it get special treatment?

items.title: Support deploy.on keys in travis:after
items.body:
It would be helpful to match the capabilities of the `deploy.on` section as much as possible, at least to the extend of what is reasonable for Python deployments. To that end, the following keys should be added, if possible:

* [ ] `repo`
* [ ] `branch`
* [ ] `condition`
* [ ] `tags`

See [The Travis docs](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/deployment#Conditional-Releases-with-on%3A) for the full list of supported keys in `deploy.on`.

ERROR: unknown environment 'py37'

items.title: `install_command` Has No Effect on Travis
items.body:
My project needs to support `pypy` and depends on `numpy`.  I use the `install_command`  for the pypy env to install `numpy` for pypy from BitBucket before installing other pakcages. Here is my `tox.ini`:

```
[tox]
envlist = py27,pypy

[testenv]
commands = pytest
deps =
    pytest-pep8
    pytest-cov
    pytest
    coverage

[testenv:pypy]
install_command = pip install git+https://bitbucket.org/pypy/numpy.git {packages}
```

This works well locally. However, `numpy` seems not installed properly on Travis-CI: the `tox` command complains that `numpy` was not installed. Here is my `.travis.yml`:

```
language: python
python:
    - "2.7"
    - "pypy"
install:
    - |
        if [[ "${TRAVIS_PYTHON_VERSION}" = pypy ]]; then
            git clone https://github.com/yyuu/pyenv.git ~/.pyenv
            PYENV_ROOT="$HOME/.pyenv"
            PATH="$PYENV_ROOT/bin:$PATH"
            eval "$(pyenv init -)"
            pyenv install pypy-5.4.1
            pyenv global pypy-5.4.1
        fi
    - pip install tox-travis coveralls
script:
    - tox

after_success:
    - coveralls
```

I have to explicit call `pip install git+https://bitbucket.org/pypy/numpy.git` in the `if` block to make Travis happy. Is this potentially a glitch of `tox-travis`?

I'm setting up pythonnet builds on both Linux and OSX using Travis CI. Previously the builds were working fine under Linux only, but with tox and tox-travis I'm only able to build on Linux 2.7

```
ERROR: invocation failed (exit code 1), logfile: /home/travis/build/pythonnet/pythonnet/.tox/py33/log/py33-1.log
ERROR: actionid: py33
```

https://travis-ci.org/pythonnet/pythonnet/jobs/163293730

items.title: pypy3 fix for missing expected binary
items.body: I am pretty confident we can provide a fixup for https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/6304 , which looks like the cause of https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/4306 .

items.title: pip creates pkg_resources.VersionConflict for Python 3.2 when tox explicitly installed
items.body:
`pip install tox-travis` works well with the new virtualenv version management feature, however `pip install tox tox-travis` fails, which is more typically going to be used like `pip install tox==2.1.1 tox-travis`.

This is only a limitation on the new auto Python 3.2 support (inc. PyPy3 2.4), and doesnt affect the PyPy3 5.2 new support.  As such, this doesnt appear to be a regression, and doesnt affect the main feature of tox-travis 0.5 which is simplifying adoption of the new PyPy3. Unless someone reports that tox-travis 0.5 is breaking their build, this bug is not a high priority.

The reason is the dependency version resolution system in pip isnt very good. Upgrading to the newest pip and setuptools doesnt fix the problem.  Here is a log showing pip deciding to installing virtualenv 15.0.2 in order to meet requirement `virtualenv>=1.11.2 (from tox)`, effectively ignoring tox-travis the requirement from tox-travis.
https://travis-ci.org/jayvdb/pyflakes/jobs/148206747#L155

Anyone using `pip install tox tox-travis`, needs to change this to `pip install tox-travis` to use the new Python 3.2 support.

If someone really needs a custom version of tox, and Python 3.2 support is also needed, the workaround is to use the old approach for Python 3.2, by installing the "virtualenv<14" explicitly.

I'm pretty sure I can see a solution, but wont be working on it in the next ~5hrs unless someone notices a regression.

items.title: Simple osx support
items.body:
While longer term ideas perculate, I think there is a simple approach possible for osx that doesnt prevent any future improvement, but is a little backwards incompatible for some edge cases.

Installing & using tox-travis on osx will currently run only the py27 testenv. Anything more complex requires a lot of ugly hacks. (Need to recheck this.)

tox-travis relies on TRAVIS_PYTHON_VERSION a lot, which is only provided with `language: python` on linux. Iirc, recently tox-travis added another similar envvar usable as an override.

Tox-travis could require this envvar is set, only on osx, or otherwise do not alter tox TOXENV. Python osx is not supported by Travis, but if it was supported it is very likely this envvar will be set.  By requiring it now, we default to normal tox behaviour on osx, but provide a clear approach for people who want to hack a fake travis support.

For the typical use of one osx job , normal tox processing will change from running the main testenv for only the default python , to running the testenv on whatever python versions are defined in `envlist`, which shouldnt break anything, however we would need to enable "skip missing interpretors" to avoid silly failures.

If someone has set the envvar manually for a osx job, it would work as before.

The backwards incompatibilities exist where someone has
- a `tox:travis` that they expect to be used on osx jobs. If they also have a normal `envlist` , it would be used and should work witbout error on osx, unless the have an osx bug.
- selected the desired python interpreter using `PATH`. They will also see all found interpreters being tested, and will be annoyed if they have multiple osx jobs retesting the same multiple interpreters. The may not notice this for a while, aa the most obvious clue will be an increase in build times.

I think these edge cases will exist in some form for any solution that provides osx support, as users are hacking around the lack of osx support by travis, in many curious ways.
I doubt there are many tox-travis users with osx jobs, but more users will arrive soon and we need a clear and simple approach for them.

items.title: PyPy3 5.2
items.body:
See https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/6277#issuecomment-232161722
 and https://bitbucket.org/hpk42/tox/issues/345/pypy3-52

I have a patch almost ready to roll, the outstanding problem is how this release should be treated in tox-travis.

Currently I have it mapping to `pypy3`, which is the worst option IMO, but I am not keen on defining new test environment factors that dont exist outside of Travis.  My preference would be to wait to see if `tox` defines a better strategy on that issue.

items.title: Runtime check for tox envs that won't run
items.body:
From @jayvdb on #16:

> It could be possible to check that the .travis.yml matrix has all of the versions that are in tox.ini [tox:travis], as a quick run-time check and warning that the two files have been set up correctly / they haven't been shoved out of sync accidentally.

items.title: Manage virtualenv dependency for py32
items.body:
tox depends on virtualenv, and virtualenv 14+ is busted on Python 3.2
While travis provides '3.2', tox-travis should also support Python 3.2, and it can make that simpler by adding a dependency on `virtualenv<14` only on Python 3.2.

Then `pip install tox-travis` will install tox and a suitable version of virtualenv .

A [similar bug](https://bitbucket.org/hpk42/tox/issues/323) exists upstream in `tox`, but they do not have a strong reason to support Python 3.2, while `tox-travis` does.

items.title: PyPy is ignored
items.body:
Here is my attempt to enable pypy via tox-travis 

https://github.com/twisted/twisted/pull/226

In the first commit I just added pypy, but it was not updated in the env list.

BTW. Why is tox-travis not running its own tests via tox-travis ? :)

items.title: Implement unified results and pipeline joining similar to travis-after-all
items.body:
Currently the `tox-travis` does not allow us to make a release if ALL travis jobs succeeded. People are probably using the travis-after-all approach on this. 

Still, it would be extremely helpful for any Python projects to integrate this into travis-tox as we do want to be able to consolidate the results of different executions and get a final single build report and do an automatic release if the outcome is positive.

items.title: Python 3.6 (nightly) problem
items.body:
Only my Python 3.6 build fails (here: https://travis-ci.org/jayvdb/csl-data/jobs/108199025 ) with

``` sh
$ pip install tox-travis
Collecting tox-travis
  Downloading tox_travis-0.3-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Collecting tox>=2.0 (from tox-travis)
  Downloading tox-2.3.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl (40kB)
    100% |████████████████████████████████| 40kB 7.8MB/s 
Collecting virtualenv>=1.11.2 (from tox>=2.0->tox-travis)
  Downloading virtualenv-14.0.6-py2.py3-none-any.whl (1.8MB)
    100% |████████████████████████████████| 1.8MB 368kB/s 
Requirement already satisfied (use --upgrade to upgrade): py>=1.4.17 in /home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages (from tox>=2.0->tox-travis)
Collecting pluggy<0.4.0,>=0.3.0 (from tox>=2.0->tox-travis)
  Downloading pluggy-0.3.1-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Installing collected packages: virtualenv, pluggy, tox, tox-travis
Successfully installed pluggy-0.3.1 tox-2.3.1 tox-travis-0.3 virtualenv-14.0.6
$ tox
```

``` python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/bin/tox", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(cmdline())
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tox/session.py", line 38, in main
    config = prepare(args)
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tox/session.py", line 26, in prepare
    config = parseconfig(args)
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tox/config.py", line 208, in parseconfig
    pm.hook.tox_addoption(parser=parser)
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pluggy.py", line 724, in __call__
    return self._hookexec(self, self._nonwrappers + self._wrappers, kwargs)
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pluggy.py", line 338, in _hookexec
    return self._inner_hookexec(hook, methods, kwargs)
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pluggy.py", line 333, in <lambda>
    _MultiCall(methods, kwargs, hook.spec_opts).execute()
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pluggy.py", line 596, in execute
    res = hook_impl.function(*args)
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tox_travis.py", line 32, in tox_addoption
    desired_envs = get_desired_envs(config, version)
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tox_travis.py", line 62, in get_desired_envs
    return split_env(travis_section.get(version, TOX_DEFAULTS.get(version)))
  File "/home/travis/virtualenv/python3.6-dev/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tox/config.py", line 801, in _split_env
    if '\n' in env:
TypeError: argument of type 'NoneType' is not iterable
```

It might be a tox bug, but if it is then I hope `tox-travis` can work around it.

items.title: Autogenerate .travis.yml
items.body:
Since we've got information on how Travis CI and Tox should talk to each other, we may be able to help implement a rudimentary `.travis.yml` file, ready for further customization. It can't be a complete solution, but it can be an easy way to start.

If possible, it would be nice for it to be some kind of a sub-command of `tox`, for instance, `tox --travis-gen` or something similar, to avoid another top-level command.

This idea originated with a comment by @henriquebastos on #4.

items.title: Support other Travis matrix factors than Python version
items.body:
Hi! This is an awesome lib. Thank you very much!!!

Is it possible to map 1 Travis env to 1 Tox env?

I have 6 env on Tox (python version x django versions) and 3 on Travis (1 for each python version).

With `tox-travis` I could only separate by the python versions. Did I missed anything?

This is `tox.ini`:

``` ini
[tox]
envlist = py{27,35}-django{18,19}, py{27,34}-django17

[tox:travis]
2.7 = py27
3.4 = py34
3.5 = py35

[testenv]
deps =
    django17: Django>=1.7,<1.8
    django18: Django>=1.8,<1.9
    django19: Django>=1.9,<1.10
    django-nose==1.4.2
    nose==1.3.7
commands = python runtests.py
```

And my `.travis.yml` is:

``` yml
language: python
python:
  - "2.7"
  - "3.4"
  - "3.5"
install:
  - pip install -q tox-travis
script:
  - tox
```

items.title: Release update to PyPI
items.body:
I've let the master branch languish and not pushed updated changes to PyPI. This causes confusion, because the README is for the master branch, not the PyPI version. Time to release to avoid some of that confusion.

Prompted by #2
